content.description: Sit start with hands matched on the large shelf.  From there, move up the slight overhang on crimps to reach a solid topout.  The arete is off for this problem.
content.protection: A few pads and a spot, the landing is uneven.
content.location: This is on the South face of Zevon Boulder.

content.description:
Sit start with hands matched on the shelf about two feet in from the west arete.  From there, traverse the shelf to the right until reaching the boulder's natural break.  At this point, throw up a heel and mantle over the lip.

The feet are good throughout the problem, the mantle for the topout is probably the toughest moment.
content.protection: A pad should do just fine, the landing is great.
content.location: This is on the South face of Zevon Boulder.

content.description:
Sit start with a low, left hand sidepull and a right hand crimp.  From there, work up and slightly left through the crimps to a juggy, solid topout.

The beginning moves are cramped, staying low on the good feet is crucial.
content.protection: A pad, the landing is great though.
content.location: This is on the North face of Zevon Boulder.

content.description: Sit start from a jug. From there, work up and left on the arete's bumps. At the apex, top it out.
content.protection: A few pads, as the problem has a few rocks that lie behind where it climbs.
content.location: This ascends the south face of Zevon Boulder.

content.description: Sit start at the arete with a left hand jug and a right hand edge. From there, hit a right hand crimp, and move the left up to a pinch. Then work the bumps at the lip and top it out (crux?).
content.protection: A few pads, the immediate landing is great, but there are rocks behind the problem.
content.location: This ascends the southwest arete of Zevon Boulder.

content.description: Sit start, move to the ledge, and move up to match on a rail. Get a heel toe cam, and shoot up left to a diagonal crack hold. Work up through a couple nice holds and top out straight up or traverse a little left and top out. There are lots of good holds on top either way.
